Can you please use in your new implementation only `BufferGeometry`? So for instance instead of `CylinderGeometry` -> `CylinderBufferGeometry` etc.
@Mugen87 done! We should also consider adding deprication warnings to old Geometry constructors.
@mrdoob I removed deprecation warnings for setter functions and reverted the examples to use them.

Interesting proposal @haroldiedema

I think all controls should handle listeners separately from control logic. Not necessarily because worker context but because the listener logic is significant and complicated enough to have it's own abstraction. 

I noticed that each control has its own implementation identical in intention but slightly varied in implementation. Also, various UX bugs emerged multiple times for nearly identical reasons in different controls.

Having a single implementation for listeners that normalizes mouse/touch and serves the purpose for all controls would greatly improve maintenability of controls and open a possibility for more sophisticated scene manipulation tools.

Anyway...

The thing you proposed should be easy to implement. Would it be OK, if handler arguments sit in an object similar to native event object? I know you can post JSON to a worker but not sure if doing so at real-time rate is an issue.
That's perfectly fine. I'm currently doing the same thing and it's smooth as butter!
Hey @haroldiedema I separated the event handlers from control logic but I imagine you will still need to make some changes to make it work inside worker context.
@haroldiedema those ES6 classes look really nice! Its the only way forward. I really hope #9562 goes through soon.
This is a super sweet example, i hope it gets merged soon!
Real improvement to the current TransformControls functionality so looking forward to this being merged. Pity it was bumped from r94 into r95.

@brettkromkamp I think it is OK to wait this one out a little since it is a full rewrite. In the meantime, if people want to test the branch and make sure controls work OK, it would be appreciated. Please report bugs here if you find any!

Also, looking at this after some time has passed, I'm wondering if two rotation modes are a the most elegant solution? Maybe it is better to go with 3dsMax style (linear gesture only) which works at any camera angle.
It's a pretty nice solution. and is it support multiple selection now ?

@easyfrog unfortunately, no multiple selection yet. I tried doing that at some point and my head almost exploded. I want to do it, as well as component transform mode (vertices, faces etc.). The first step for this would be to define a data structure for selection say `THREE.Selection` and then attach `TransformControls` to it as if it was a regular `Object3D`. Then perhaps `THREE.Selection` could apply transformations to its members. If anyone have any ideas and implementation suggestions, I am all ears.
Looking forward to it! I will use it in my project, after adapting to typescript!

@AustinDuvin see discussion #14619

Are you using OrbitControls or some other?

If you want to make TransformControls work nicely with any other control, look at editor Viewport.js and how it handles multiple controls.

The reason TransformControls used to work alongside OrbitControls with no setup was quite an ugly hack that involved event.stopPropagation(). Instead of re-introducing the hack, I provided a simple way to rig multiple controls in #14619 (see TransformControls example in that branch)

If you provide me with a code sample of your controls I can assist you further.

Okay, I implemented the changes and now it's working fine. It seems to have had some problems depending on when the controls were created and added to the scene. It may just be that the way it interacts with other parts of the software I'm working on caused some issues where it tried to create the controls before the scene had fully loaded or been created. I'm not entirely sure what the cause of the problem was, but it is no longer an issue. Thank you.
